c74object.name: bach.reducefunction
c74object.description: Simplifies a breakpoint function by pruning negligible points.

attribute.name: algorithm
attribute.description:
Sets the algorithm used to approximate the function.
- Clustering: Points are grouped in cluster, and mid-points are pruned. The thresh attribute in this case sets the maximum average distance of the points with respect to the line obtained with the pruned points, for clustering. The result keeps well isolated the different function regions.
- Greedy Clustering: Same as previous one, but the search is performed greedily left-to-right. Result is usually faster than previous case, but of a lower quality.
- Integral Approximation: The algorithm approximates the function by starting with the first and last point, and subsequently adding one by one some mid-points, until the integral distance (depending on the p value) is under the thresh threshold.

attribute.name: maxnumpoints
attribute.description: (For Integral Approximation algorithm only.) Sets the maximum number of output points. Leave 0 to mean: no limit.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the followings:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.
llllobj_class_add_check_attr(c, LLLL_OBJ_VANILLA);

attribute.name: p
attribute.description: (For Integral Approximation algorithm only.) Sets the value of the index p, determining the type of norm. Such value can be an integer greater or equal than 1, or can be the symbol "inf", for the infinite norm. In general, the p-norm of a function is calculated by taking the p-th root of the integral of the absolute value of the function raised to the p-th power. The inf-norm, on the other hand, is the absolute value of the "sup" of the function (which coincides with the function maximum for breakpoint functions).

attribute.name: relative
attribute.description: Toggles the ability for the threshold defined by thresh to be a relative threshold (with respect to the function domain and range). By default it is on. For instance, for Clustering algorithms, setting thresh as 0.1 will mean that an error of 10% of the range is acceptable. For Integral algorithm, this also accounts for the domain: the given thresh is thus an integral threshold per domain unit and per range unit. For instance, if thresh is 0.9, domain spans 3 units and range spans 7 units, it means that an error of 0.9*3*7 is still acceptable.

attribute.name: thresh
attribute.description: Sets the distance threshold for a simplified curve to be acceptable. For Clustering algorithms, this is the average distance of the points with respect to the segment created by pruning them (default: 0.025). For Integral algorithms, this is the integral distance between the function and the simplified one (also see p).
